Elliotte Harold wrote:

> If the behavior is general enough that you want it to be public *for
> reasons other than testing* then by all means, go ahead and make it
> public. But don't let the tail wag the dog. If the only reason you want
> it public is for testing, then use the public interface instead.


If the only reason I want it public is for testing, I can't remember an 
instance where I didn't find a way of making it public so that it also 
did make sense for other reasons than testing.

So in my experience, a private test-worthy method is an abstraction 
waiting to be found and extracted.

That's one of the reasons test driven development is so damn useful, 
after all.

Cheers, Ilja
